hints.content: To divide a shape in thirds, we divide the whole into **$3$ equal parts**.

These circles are divided into $3$ pieces, but the pieces are not equal in size:  

![2 circles. The first is divided into 3 unequal pieces with 2 parallel lines dividing the circle. The second is divided into 3 unequal pieces with 2 large pieces and 1 small piece.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/1c34d7c17f5f846370b4e537bb2f0f36a2b17f38) ![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/d3ea9fb4e8ce7d47e5a20e0e8950d34f845ab412)

These circles are divided into thirds:  

![2 circles. Each circle is divided into 3 equal parts.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f412b01c95675fc87bca643892b0dc09f81fc1d7) ![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/aa63d162c6a0a4a6624e458a56fefdc50274ef18)

question.content:
**Which circles are divided into thirds?**

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: ![A circle has 2 parallel lines passing through it. The lines divide the circle in 3 sections.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/1c34d7c17f5f846370b4e537bb2f0f36a2b17f38)

![A circle is divided into 3 unequal parts. 2 parts are almost half the circle. The third part is a very small section.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/d3ea9fb4e8ce7d47e5a20e0e8950d34f845ab412)
